Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Effectively transparent contacts for solar applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact of this I-Corps project is to increase the efficiency of solar modules by up to 6%, a significant improvement in the photovoltaics (PV) space. This project replacies standard screen-printed metal contacts with an effectively transparent contacts (ETC) where the shading loss is brought down to 0%. A significant fraction of the PV ecosystem will benefit from this technology. ETCs can enable solar module manufacturers to fabricate up to 6% higher relative efficiency solar modules. This higher efficiency can lead to reduced cost overall for land use, transportation, installation and cleaning. Therefore, the levelized cost of electricity (LCOE) can potentially be reduced and photovoltaic electricity can become more affordable.

This I-Corps project further develops effectively transparent contacts (ETC) that mitigate shading losses inherent to screen-printed metal contacts over the entire solar spectrum and for all angles of incidence. ETCs are triangular cross-section micro-scale metal contacts that redirect the incoming light efficiently to the active area of the solar cell. Overcoming front contact shading loss without reducing the grid conductivity increases the silicon solar cell power output by up to 6%. When replacing standard screen-printed metal contacts with ETCs the amount of used silver can also be reduced. The ETC's are made via a residue-free three-dimensional micro-imprint process that enables large scale printing of ETCs by solar module manufactures. To date, the integration of ETCs with state-of-the-art silicon heterojunction solar cells has been successfully demonstrated on a laboratory scale.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Team ETC Solar participated in I-Corps and conducted over 150 customer discovery interviews within the solar industry to potentially identify product market fit for a new solar technology developed at Caltech. We found that solar cell manufacturers are dealing with razor thin margins and the constant push for efficiency increase and manufacturing cost reduction. In addition, the team learned that innovative technologies are required to prolong growth and extend market share of the solar cell manufacturers (potential customers).

Prior to I-Corps, the team was convinced the potential market opportunity for our technology was located in China, since most solar cell manufacturers are located in that area. However, after conducting the first customer interviews, the team learned that new technologies are typically first adopted by U.S. and European solar manufacturers since they are driven by innovation rather than mass manufacturing. For that reason, team ETC Solar decided to conduct more customer interviews with these European and U.S. solar cell manufacturers to learn about the problems these potential customers are facing. 

After conducting about 25 customer interviews, the team learned and identified different customer segments within the solar industry including III-V, thin-film and silicon solar cell manufacturers. The team learned that the customers within these different customer segments are facing different problems and are driven by different metrics. For example, the III-V solar cell manufacturers are driven by efficiency increase and not so much by costs, while to the silicon solar cell manufacturers cost is critical. From customer feedback ETC Solar was able to identify the different problems these potential customers are facing  and express the value proposition of the technology.

All in all, ETC Solar identified product market fit with the solar cell manufacturers and was able to find a beachhead market: III-V solar cell manufacturer. Furthermore, ETC Solar was able to get a good understanding of the value proportion of the technology to the potential customer.

Besides the solar cell manufacturers (potential customers) the team also conducted interviews with other stakeholders within the PV industry including business developers, end-users, installers, material suppliers and equipment manufacturers. Thereby, the business model was refined and a global understanding of the solar industry was obtained. In addition, the broad network gained through the I-Corps program is seen by the team as highly valuable and critical to successfully commercialize this innovative solar technology from Caltech.

After identifying product-market fit, refining our business model and obtaining a broad global network through the I-Corps program, the team of ETC Solar incorporated and is currently commercializing world's highest-performing front contact technology for solar cells: effectively transparent contacts (ETCs).


Last Modified: 10/29/2018
Modified by: Harry A Atwater
